data.stimulus:
Quick Reading

► Read the text quickly. 

► You should spend about 10 minutes reading the text and answering the questions.

 

Choose the best HEADING to summarise each section from the options below (drag and drop).

► NOTE: There is one extra heading that you don't need.

value: Popular now but not in future?

options.label: Because fashion is associated with novelty and consumption.
Because fashion is associated with habits and style.
Because fashion is associated with luxury and extravagance.

data.stimulus:
Detailed Reading 

► Follow the steps below: 

 

  • STEP 1:  Read the questions below before you read the text. 

► This will help you focus on the information you are looking for.

  • STEP 2:   Read the text quickly. Spend about 5 minutes reading. 

► Don't stop for vocabulary (you can do this in the next step).

  • STEP 3:   Look at the questions again one by one - find the part in the text where you think the answers are.

► Read this part carefully. Check vocabulary  if necessary.

  • STEP 4:   Answer the question and move on to the next one.

► Don't forget to check your answers - you have ONE attempt to check.

 

 


Remember: the order of the questions follows the order of the text.

This means that the answer to question 1 should be in the beginning of the text, the answer to question 2 should be after that, and so on....

 

 

 

1. Why is it difficult for fashion to be sustainable?

► Read the text carefully! You have only ONE 'check answer' attempt!

options.label: Clothes were very dull-looking and unattractive
Clothes were very expensive and there wasn't a lot of choice
Clothes were very boring and costly

data.stimulus:

14. According to the text, are fashion designers and retailers taking note of sustainability issues?

► Read the text carefully! You have only ONE 'check answer' attempt!

In this part of the lesson, we will focus on Critical Reading.

► What is Critical Reading?

Critical Reading means examining the text and actively asking questions of the source, in order to understand its relevance and reliability for your own research topic (University of Leeds 2021).

 

 

► Look at the SKILLS and STRATEGIES below. Are they important for Critical Reading?
data.template:
• Consider what kind of text it is (is it a book, an academic journal, a magazine, ... ?) {{response}}
  •  Consider the text purpose (why did the author write it?) {{response}}
  • Consider the audience (is it for professionals, students, general public, ... ?) {{response}}
  • Translate the text to your own language. {{response}}
  • Did the writer use evidence? Does the text have a reference list? {{response}}
  • Compare the information in the text with other information you already know. {{response}}
  • Memorise the key points. {{response}}

  • Consider how the text is useful for your assignment. {{response}}

value: learn something and to write an assignment.

possible_responses: learn something and to write an assignment.
data.stimulus:
How to Read Critically

► What do you think is the difference between reading critically and reading for pleasure (for example, reading a fiction book or a short story)?
data.template:
• The purpose for reading critically, is usually to {{response}}.
  • Critical reading will usually require you to read the same text {{response}}.
  • Critical reading involves coming back to it a number of times to {{response}}.

value: learn something and to write an assignment.
What kind of text is this? Who is the audience? Is this text useful for my assignment?
What is the argument in the text? What is the writer's viewpoint? How / Where does it fit in my assignment? Do I agree with the points made?
What’s the main idea? What are the supporting points? Are there examples or evidence? Prepare the reference list entry and in-text citation.
What is MY argument? How can I use this text to support it? Paraphrasing: how can I say the same thing in different words?
Are there any more ideas I want to use?

possible_responses: What is the argument in the text? What is the writer's viewpoint? How / Where does it fit in my assignment? Do I agree with the points made?
What is MY argument? How can I use this text to support it? Paraphrasing: how can I say the same thing in different words?

What’s the main idea? What are the supporting points? Are there examples or evidence? Prepare the reference list entry and in-text citation.
Are there any more ideas I want to use?
data.stimulus:
So, in order to use the text in your assignment you should be able to READ CRITICALLY.
